ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Great practicum to get some 'real world' experience.

The 'excellence' of the course, as I described it, is entirely contingent on the projects a student is working on. In my case, I had one fantastic project, and one project that was okay. Altogether, the process was very valuable.That said, Jim seems to know how to select projects that will pay off.

This is not a traditional lecture-style class, so take some responses with a grain of salt.Question4: workload was A LOT heavier than other courses. I'm sure everyone will comment on this, and has been for the past couple of years, so I don't understand why it hasn't changed. It should either be a two project/6 credit course (though I heard that it's impossible to do that if the professor is not tenured...) or a one project/3 credit class.Question 9: I think it's important to meet clients once in the beginning and once at the end, but it still felt like a lot of traveling. For one project, the final meeting seemed unnecessary, as the client seemed uninterested. Also, the instructor and TA were unclear about what could get reimbursed, and how to do that. So I ended up spending a lot of money on my own for food, metros, etc.
Working with clients.
Presenting projects to clients in person.

I loved that this is a practicum course--I think everyone should take such a capstone project course. I learned so much from working with clients on real-life, applicable projects that I don't learn in more traditional, lecture-based courses. Not to say that one is better than the other, I just usually get more lecture than practicum.
The projects were terrific and getting to meet leaders at environmental non-profits was an incredibly valuable learning experience.
The chance of working with real projects, with real problems faced by our clients
The opportunity to work for the non profit and is excellent way to prep oneself of consulting work.

The best part of this course is working on a real project with a client and doing research for them. Working with a group is also a great chance to learn from your classmates and taking trips down to DC is a great way to learn how politics work and how the city works too.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Coordination with professor for class time .

Project assignments that are too broad in scope and/or require a subject expertise that cannot be gained over the course of a single semester. All project designers need to consider the circumstances as they design research questions: students come from very different backgrounds and have big workloads on top of this course.

The workload, it's so much. I felt like I worked more on one project than I did for my entire master's project, and that was just one of the two projects! Either scale down the projects' scopes, or cut one out. There are many other practicum classes at FES to look at for examples, such as the Land Conservation course.

I think other people have said this before but it is perhaps worth saying again that completing one project instead of two would have really raised the quality of our work and possibly our experience. It would also make this class's work-load more manageable and reasonable.

I was really looking forward to learn more about the US political system, but due to issues with the professor not being able to travel to campus, we skipped a lot of class sessions. NO make-up classes
The course scheduling must be reviewed along with the work assigned.

This course is a tremendous amount of work. I think this course should have 1 project, instead of 2, per student so that students can deliver a very high quality report rather than be stretched over two huge projects throughout the semester. It was also challenging to do the projects when the professor didn't give feedback on reports until the end of the semester when there wasn't much time left to make changes and do further research. The professor also should have been more available and responsive.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The TA was extremely responsive!The instructor was responsive but hard to get a hold of at times for feedback on the projects. Because of the nature of the course and the fact that the professor is working in Washington, DC, made it slightly difficult to get all the class time/discussion time in.
It took too long for the instructor to get comments back to the groups.
Never sought help.
ok
The TA was available for logistical arrangements while the instructor is available via email but often the responses/comments were delayed especially when we needed the responses much earlier.
The instructor missed a number of the classes and also did not provide feedback on the midterm reports for a few weeks, leaving little time for edits for the final drafts.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Great course to get your feet wet in the policy arena.

I'm studying environmental science, issues, and policy in the hopes of applying these disciplines in an advocacy or policy setting when I graduate. This course let me experience that work right away, which will greatly inform my further studies and career plans.
This is a great opportunity, it might lead you to a job opening. You will be dealing with client working on important issues and your work will be used by them
As a person interested in Policy, the opportunity to work with a non profit conservation agency in a report to support them is an added benefit.

This course taught me about policy, research, nonprofits in D.C. and about renewable energy (my projects were focused on this). I am interested in corporate sustainability so this course gave me a great view into policy-making and research reports used to form policy.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Very interested in learning about policy work.

I'd had multiple bad experiences with group projects and wanted to have a good one, which turned out to be the case in this class. It is also valuable to do work that is eventually presented to clients, as in this way you are truly accountable for the quality.
As an MEM, it was critical in my opinion to get professional, practical experience in this field.
To get experience working on environmental policy in the US.
For hands-on experience, it was great.
The opportunity to work as a 'Consultant' for a non profit conservation agency.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes.
Yes.
Yes, I got the experience I sought, learned a lot, and also made many contacts.
Yes!
No, considering I wanted more from the class sessions
Yes. It was good but bit hectic.
Yes, this course lived up to my expectations but was much more work and incredibly time-consuming during the last 4 weeks of the semester. The research we did was also less-thorough than I expected.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes. Probably more!
Yes.
YEs, see above.
Yes!
See 17
Yes. Very much.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Loved the group work. Really taught you how to schedule and manage your time and communicate with group members.
Standard challenges were difficult, but groups bring perspective to a problem and, ultimately, tend to produce a product that has a sum greater than its parts.

Advantage: divvying up the work, it would have been impossible otherwise.Disadvantage: often times, it ended up being a lot of work anyway, because we had to peer edit each other's sections. THis is because we all think/write/cite differently but didn't realize that till after everything was written, so there was a lot of editing. You can't be in control of style, which led to disagreements within one of my groups about how the content should be presented. It is frustrating working with others who are not responsive to emails, don't do an equal amount of work, and show up late or don't show up at all to meetings. But such is group work in general.

It was absolutely essential for our groups to work well together on our projects. I learned a great deal about how to manage time, work with others, and use the strengths of different team members to produce a fantastic product.
It was great, you get learn to work with two groups on two different projects and deal with deadlines and communication. Great experience

Advantages were that you are brainstorming, discussing and working together which makes the work much easier.Disadvantages were that a lot of time spent on group discussion and brainstorming and it was hard bring all the team members to come together.

The group work helped us be able to deliver a high quality report to the client and to cover a large research question with many components. It also allowed us to each specialize in an aspect of the research. Disadvantages were that group work is time-consuming for meetings, and at times group members did not do their portions of the work and so some group members had to do double the work load to make up for this.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Make sure your course load is light aside from this class. It picked up dramatically (work load) after spring break!!
Start early and keep a good line of communication open with the client. The closer you are to the client, the better your project will go - both the research and presentation.
Take a lighter 4th course--this course will consume your a lot of your time!
Get ready for a lot of work. Make sure your other classes are easy. And start writing as early as possible. Get as much done before spring break as possible.
Take it, much better to take this class than many others on FES. Butpush your Professor for the class sessions. He knows a lot and you should take advantage of it and learn as much as you can.

Its a great class to if you want to do consulting with conservation agencies. A lot of work is done outside of class and time commitment is much more than it seems while prepare yourself of a hectic schedule at the end of the semester (presentation, final report etc).

This is an excellent course and you will learn a lot about policy and current environmental issues such as renewable energy. It's a fantastic chance to work with clients and nonprofit organizations in Washington D.C. and to get to know the city and how policy is formed. You will do a TON of work, especially in the last 4 weeks of the semester. But it's worth it and you end up with a great report written by you and your group members and often this can lead to internship offers and at least some great connections in D.C. The professor was somewhat hard to reach and it took a while to get feedback on reports. Sometimes you'll have to pull double weight in your group. Just be prepared for a very heavy course load and try to jump on the project early in the semester!
